I'll try to explain this ages old video my best.
When holding, the tension in the spring is exactly equal to weight of slinky. This is because the tension is provided by our handing holding the slinky up and stopping it from falling. When we release, due to weight and tension acting in the same direction the top part of slinky has no balancing force so it goes down, whereas the bottom part still experiences upward tension balancing its weight. When the slinky contracts completely, there is no displacement (hookes law) so no force is acting on the slinky except gravity so it falls down. Correct me if I'm wrong thanks.

I'm not a physicist, but it seems clear each part of the slinky is
being supported by the tension in the part of the coil immediately above it.

Until it collapses, the coil above it is still exerting its upward force which
exactly counteracts gravity. 

As soon as the coil right above a given point collapses, there is no upward
force and that part of the slinky drops.

Why make it sound like a mystery?

The tension in the coil generates the force that supports everything below it.
As long as the tension is there the force remains, nothing below it will drop.
As soon as the tension is gone, there is no more force and the part below
it but above the remaining coils that still have tension will fall.

It's got nothing to do with information.

I we set up a light source at the top of the slinky that emits light
when the person releases the top of the slinky and if we set up a
light detector at the bottom of the slinky such that a switch is flipped
when it receives the light from the top, the fact that information has
arrived at the bottom of the slinky flipping the switch will not make
the bottom of the slinky fall, even though the information has arrived
at the bottom of the slinky telling it that the top of the slinky has been released.

the reason the slinky bottom stays is because its in equilibrium b4 releasing it. when you hold the top part  in the air the slinky stretches to a certain point, that point is where the  bottom is in equilibrium with gravity. so it dont matter if you  connect it with something heavy it will just trech more and reach a new equilibrium agian when the strech force is equal to gravity the slicky wil stop streching and reach is position. the equilibrium stays until the force reaches the last twist of the slinky thats why it just float in air

Picture it this way. Place the slinky on the ground coiled vertically. Pinch the top few turns between your fingers and draw the slinky up. As you pull the slinkys top up the bottom of the slinky remains on the ground and will not lift until there is a uniform tension along the slinkys length. This is what's happening when the slinky is dropped only in reverse.

In the first instance the top is accelerated down at 2*9.8m/s^2. After that the acceleration decreases to 9.8m/s^2 when the slinkie is fully compressed.
IMPORTANT: This is without any friction! The force would still be the same (9.8N/kg) with friction, but the acceleration is lessened.

So hypothetically, if were to make a really big Slinky, tied myself to the end of it and let it drop from a great height, I'd levitate for a few moments?!

First, you'd need to find a material that had the ductility needed to make a slinky that could also suspend your weight at equilibrium. Then, you would need to make that long enough to observe and keep very still. You wouldn't feel zero gravity - you would feel the tension of being held by the spring. If released, it would take a moment for the tension to "catch up" with you, whereupon you would then feel gravity more than tension and fall.

My reasoning for KE is similar to Newton's Cradle. The same number of balls bounce up as were pulled back. Does it cost more energy to accelerate the entire slinky downward while collapsing it than to accelerate the top of the slinky faster and then accelerate the collapsed slinky downward? The top of the slinky is like 1 ball on the Cradle, and the whole slinky is like 2 balls.

Adding yourself to the slinky is no different than adding anything else to the slinky. The point is that the force that was keeping you up is still there until it finally goes away after you release the slinky.

It's like if you and a friend were holding a metal rod and your friend taps their end. You won't feel anything until the wave travels through the rod to you.

This actually affects everything we interact with, it's just that most objects are 'solid' enough to not notice.

I would say no. Chains don't work through a tension or the force from a spring, but rather from the normal force (the force felt between two objects in contact) between the different links. The normal force on every link would ultimately depend on the normal force felt by the very top link, which you'd be holding a finger I suppose. Once take your finger out from the top every normal force would disappear so the only force acting on each link would be gravity; they'd all fall at the same rate.

not entirely true, the problem is that people use centrifugal to describe the wrong force vector. centrifugal force is the reaction vector to the centripetal force. Force instance, on a tether the centripetal force is the force of the tether on the object in motion, while the centrifugal force is the force of the tether on the anchor.

Actually, the center of mass would be accelerating with 9.81m/s² and not moving with 9.81m/s. The top part sees a bigger accelerating force with gravity and the spring combined and the bottom part sees a smaller force resulting from gravity minus the spring force (absolute values), in this case zero.
So if you exactly want the answer about the speed you also need to consider time. The center of mass reaches that speed after 1 second and the top part considerably faster.

The bottom is affected by spring tension (up) and gravitational pull (down) and remains at rest. The top, on the other hand, has both forces (tension and gravity) pulling it downwards so it has to be moving down (until it hits the bottom and they both fall down because of the momentum transferred).

Your theory is correct! There are 2 forces acting on the top coils, gravity pulling them down and a spring force pulling them down. These two forces add to make it so that the total force is bigger than just gravity. However, the center of mass of the spring has only one force acting on it, gravity (the up and down spring forces cancel themselves out). So, if you dropped a ball and a slinky at the same time, the slinky would race ahead of the ball but their centers would hit at the same time.
